Goodbye Lullaby , Lavigne 's fourth album , is expected to be much more personal than her earlier records , with Lavigne describing the album as `` more stripped down , deeper . All the songs are very emotional '' .
Only a month after completing The Best Damn Tour , Lavigne began recording in her home studio in November 2008 with the song `` Black Star '' , written to help promote her first fragrance of the same name .
`` Darlin '' was the second song Lavigne wrote as a 15-year-old while living in Napanee , Ontario .
The result was the song `` Alice '' , which was played over the end credits and included on the soundtrack , Almost Alice .
Subsequent singles , `` Sk8er Boi '' and `` I 'm With You '' reached the top ten in the U.S. Thanks to the success of her first three singles , Lavigne was the second artist in history to have three # 1 songs from a debut album on the Billboard Mainstream Top 40 .
With the exception of the album 's lead single , `` What the Hell '' , Lavigne described the songs on the album as different from her earlier material : `` I 'm older now , so I think that comes across in my music , it 's not as pop-rock '' .
In response to these delays , Lavigne said , `` I write my own music and , therefore , it takes me longer to put out records 'cause I have to live my life to get inspiration , '' and that she had enough material for two records .
In June 2005 , Whibley surprised Lavigne with a trip to Venice , including a gondola ride and a romantic picnic , and on 27 June , he proposed to her .
She stated , `` It 's so easy for me to do a boy-bashing pop song , but to sit down and write honestly about something that 's really close to me , something I 've been through , it 's a totally different thing . ''
Lavigne described the album as being about `` life '' .
The release dates for Goodbye Lullaby and its lead single were pushed back several times .
Lavigne and Deryck Whibley , lead singer and guitarist for the band Sum 41 , began dating when she was 19 years old , after being friends since she was 17 .
The marriage lasted a little over three years , and in October 2009 , Lavigne filed for divorce .
On 28 February , Lavigne gave a performance at the concert portion of the Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympics closing ceremony , performing `` My Happy Ending '' and `` Girlfriend '' .
In January 2010 , while simultaneously writing and recording for her new album , Lavigne worked with Disney on Alice in Wonderland-themed clothing designs , inspired by Tim Burton 's feature film , Alice in Wonderland .
Several of the tracks were written in Lavigne 's youth .
She asked the executives if she could write a song for the film .
The lead single , `` What the Hell '' , premiered on Dick Clark 's New Year 's Rockin ' Eve on 31 December .
In November , Lavigne was featured in Maxim , where she revealed that Goodbye Lullaby took two and a half years to complete , but she cited her record company as the reason for the album 's delays , stating that the album had been completed for a year . .
By July 2009 , nine tracks had been recorded for the new album , including the songs `` Fine '' , `` Everybody Hurts '' and `` Darlin '' .
Goodbye Lullaby is scheduled to be released on 8 March .

A&M Records Ltd. was established in 1970 , with distribution handled by other labels with a presence in Europe .
A&M releases were initially issued in the United Kingdom by EMI 's Stateside Records label , and then under its own name by Pye Records until 1967 .
The company was subsequently renamed A&M , after Alpert 's and Moss 's initials .
Their first choice for a name was Carnival Records , under which they released two singles before discovering another label had taken the Carnival name first .
In 1979 , A&M entered a distribution agreement with RCA Records -LRB- which later became BMG -RRB- in the USA , and with CBS Records -LRB- whose successor Sony Music Entertainment later absorbed BMG -RRB- in many other countries .
From 1966 to 1999 , the company 's headquarters were on the grounds of the historic Charlie Chaplin Studios at 1416 North La Brea Avenue , near Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood .

A&M Records was formed in 1962 by Herb Alpert and Jerry Moss .
Within a decade of its inception , A&M became the world 's largest independent record company .
In informal situations , the term begging the question is often used in place of circular argument . In the formal context , however , begging the question holds a different meaning .
Begging the question does not require any such reversal . Begging the question is similar to the fallacy of many questions : a fallacy of technique that results from presenting evidence in support of a conclusion that is less likely to be accepted , rather than merely asserting the conclusion .

Houghton House was built in 1621 by Mary , Countess of Pembroke and sister of the poet Sir Philip Sidney .
The castle was built in the 15C by Sir John Cornwall , later Lord Fanhope , from ransoms after the Battle of Agincourt .

The name ` Ampthill ' is of Anglo-Saxon origin . The first settlement was called ` Aemethyll ' , which literally means either ` ant-heap ' or ` ant infested hill ' .
Although the Castle is now gone , some intriguing indications of castle life remain - such as the local ponds -LRB- Westminster pond being one -RRB- allegedly built to supply the castle with regular supplies of fish .
Henry VIII was a frequent visitor to Ampthill Castle , and it was there that Katherine of Aragon lived from 1531 until divorced in 1533 , when she was moved to Kimbolton .
In the Domesday Book , Ampthill is referred to as ` Ammetelle ' , with the landholder in 1086 being Nigel de la Vast .

Both practical and theoretical research continues , and many national government and military funding agencies support quantum computing research to develop quantum computers for both civilian and national security purposes , such as cryptanalysis .
A theoretical model is the quantum Turing machine , also known as the universal quantum computer .
Although quantum computing is still in its infancy , experiments have been carried out in which quantum computational operations were executed on a very small number of qubits -LRB- quantum bits -RRB- .
The basic principle behind quantum computation is that quantum properties can be used to represent data and perform operations on these data .
Although quantum computers may be faster than classical computers , those described above ca n't solve any problems that classical computers ca n't solve , given enough time and memory -LRB- however , those amounts might be practically infeasible -RRB- .
A quantum computer is a device for computation that makes direct use of quantum mechanical phenomena , such as superposition and entanglement , to perform operations on data .
For more details on the sequences of operations used for various quantum algorithms , see universal quantum computer , Shor 's algorithm , Grover 's algorithm , Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm , amplitude amplification , quantum Fourier transform , quantum gate , quantum adiabatic algorithm and quantum error correction .
The Borkum and Helgoland camps were `` volunteer '' -LRB- Hilfswillige -RRB- labor camps and the labourers in those camps were treated harshly but marginally better than the inmates at the Sylt and Norderney camps .
In 1942 , Lager Norderney , containing Russian and Polish POWs , and Lager Sylt , holding Jews , were placed under the control of the SS HauptsturmfÃ 1\/4 hrer Max List .
-LRB- For further information on Alderney concentration camps , see Appendix F : Concentration Camps : EndlÃ sung â `` The Final Solution ; Alderney , a Nazi concentration camp on an island Anglo-Norman ; for further information on Nazi treatment of Jews and other people , see -RRB- .
Lager Helgoland was filled with Russian Organisation Todt workers .
Sylt camp held Jewish enforced labourers and was a death camp .
It was organised by the Schutzstaffel - SS-Baubrigade I -- which was first under supervision of the Sachsenhausen concentration camp ; and since mid-February 1943 ran under the Neuengamme camp in northern Germany .
The Germans built four concentration camps on the island , subcamps of the Neuengamme concentration camp -LRB- located in Hamburg , Germany -RRB- .
Lager Norderney was a Nazi concentration camp on Alderney , in the Channel Islands , named after the East Frisian island of Norderney .
700 people died in the Alderney concentration camps -LRB- out of a total inmate population of about 6,000 -RRB- .
Each subcamp was named after one of the Frisian Islands : Lager Norderney located at Saye , Lager Borkum at Platte Saline , Lager Sylt near the old telegraph tower at La FoulÃ re and Lager Helgoland , situated in the northwest corner of the island .
It was used by the Nazi Organisation Todt , a forced labor program , to build bunkers , gun emplacements , air-raid shelters , and concrete fortifications .
Norderney camp housed European -LRB- usually Eastern but including Spaniard -RRB- and Russian enforced labourers .
Over 700 of the inmates lost their lives before the camps were closed and the remaining inmates transferred to Germany in 1944 .
Lager Borkum was used for German technicians and volunteers from different countries of Europe .
The prisoners in Lager Norderney and Lager Sylt were slave labourers forced to build the many military fortifications and installations throughout Alderney .
These were the only Nazi concentration camps on British soil .

The document affirms Russia 's stand on Taiwan as `` an inalienable part of China '' -LRB- A5 -RRB- , and highlights the commitment to ensure the `` national unity and territorial integrity '' in the two countries -LRB- A4 -RRB- .
Controversially , Article 9 of the treaty can be seen as an implicit defense pact , and other articles -LRB- A7 and A16 -RRB- point at increasing military cooperation , including the sharing of `` military know-how '' -LRB- A16 -RRB- , namely , Chinese access to Russian military technology .
Both the PRC and Russia fear an encroachment by the United States -LRB- especially following its strengthened geopolitical position following the September 11 , 2001 attacks -RRB- involving areas which they view as belonging to their respective spheres of national influences and interests : for the PRC , this largely involves Taiwan serving as a US client state , while for Russia it involves having various former Soviet Republics as US client states .

Trees grow shorter towards the inhospitable climate until they simply stop growing .
Trees can often grow in river valleys at latitudes where they could not grow on a more exposed site .

Maritime influences such as ocean currents also play a major role in determining how far from the equator trees can grow .
At the tree line , tree growth is often very stunted , with the last trees forming low , densely matted bushes .
The tree line , like many other natural lines -LRB- lake boundaries , for example -RRB- , appears well-defined from a distance , but upon sufficiently close inspection , it is a gradual transition in most places .
If it is caused by wind , it is known as krummholz formation , from the German for ` twisted wood ' .
In Israel , Blanford 's foxes escape competition with red foxes by restricting themselves to rocky cliffs and actively avoiding the open plains inhabited by red foxes . Red foxes dominate kit and swift foxes .
Grey foxes are exceptional , as they dominate red foxes wherever their ranges meet .
Red foxes are serious competitors of corsac foxes , as they hunt the same prey all year .
Main article : List of Melbourne railway stations .
Centered on commonly available modern foods , the `` contemporary '' Paleolithic diet consists mainly of meat , fish , vegetables , fruit , roots , and nuts , and excludes grains , legumes , dairy products , salt , refined sugar , and processed oils .
A common theme in evolutionary medicine , Paleolithic nutrition is based on the premise that modern humans are genetically adapted to the diet of their Paleolithic ancestors and that human genetics have scarcely changed since the dawn of agriculture , and therefore that an ideal diet for human health and well-being is one that resembles this ancestral diet . Proponents of this diet argue that modern human populations subsisting on traditional diets allegedly similar to those of Paleolithic hunter-gatherers are largely free of diseases of affluence , and that two small prospective studies of the Paleolithic diet in humans have shown some positive health outcomes .
Gastroenterologist Walter L. Voegtlin was one of the first to suggest that following a diet similar to that of the Paleolithic era would improve a person 's health .
Food groups that advocates claim were rarely or never consumed by humans before the Neolithic -LRB- agricultural -RRB- revolution are excluded from the diet , mainly grains , legumes -LRB- e.g. beans and peanuts -RRB- , dairy products , salt , refined sugar and processed oils , Unlike raw food diets , all foods may be cooked , without restrictions .
However , there are also raw , paleolithic dieters who believe that humans have not adapted to cooked foods , and so they eat only foods which are both raw and paleolithic .
In 2010 , this book was wholly revised , updated and published for the first time in English .
In 1975 , he published a book in which he argued that humans are carnivorous animals and that the ancestral Paleolithic diet was that of a carnivoreâ '' chiefly fats and protein , with only small amounts of carbohydrates .
As such , this nutritional approach included skimmed milk , whole-grain bread , brown rice , and potatoes prepared without fat , on the premise that such foods supported a diet with the same macronutrient composition as the Paleolithic diet .
Paleolithic nutrition has its roots in evolutionary biology and is a common theme in evolutionary medicine .
In 2003 , Lindeberg published a Swedish language medical textbook on the subject .
However , Loren Cordain has stated that the new evidence shows only sporadic consumption of grains , and he has also pointed out that that consumption of wild grass seeds of any kind requires extensive technology and processing to yield a digestible and edible food that likely did not exist 105,000 + years ago .
more than 100,000 years ago , and perhaps as early as 200,000 years ago .
Starting with the first publication in 1993 , the Kitava Study has subsequently generated a number of scientific publications on the relationship between diet and western disease .
According to S. Boyd Eaton , `` we are the heirs of inherited characteristics accrued over millions of years ; the vast majority of our biochemistry and physiology are tuned to life conditions that existed before the advent of agriculture some 10,000 years ago .
The modern dietary regimen known as the Paleolithic diet -LRB- abbreviated paleo diet or paleodiet -RRB- , also popularly referred to as the caveman diet , Stone Age diet and hunter-gatherer diet , is a nutritional plan based on the presumed ancient diet of wild plants and animals that various human species habitually consumed during the Paleolithic eraâ '' a period of about 2.5 million years duration that ended around 10,000 years ago with the development of agriculture .
In common usage , such terms as the `` Paleolithic diet '' also refer to the actual ancestral human diet .
In 1985 , S. Boyd Eaton and Melvin Konner , both of Emory University , published a key paper on Paleolithic nutrition in the New England Journal of Medicine , which allowed the dietary concept to gain mainstream medical recognition .
Three years later , S. Boyd Eaton , Marjorie Shostak and Melvin Konner published a book about this nutritional approach , which was based on achieving the same proportions of nutrients -LRB- fat , protein , and carbohydrates , as well as vitamins and minerals -RRB- as were present in the diets of late Paleolithic people , not on excluding foods that were not available before the development of agriculture .
In 1989 , these authors published a second book on Paleolithic nutrition .
These surveys , collectively referred to as the Kitava Study , found that this population apparently did not suffer from stroke , ischemic heart disease , diabetes , obesity or hypertension .
Genetically our bodies are virtually the same as they were at the end of the Paleolithic era some 20,000 years ago . ''
First popularized in the mid 1970s by gastroenterologist Walter L. Voegtlin , this nutritional concept has been promoted and adapted by a number of authors and researchers in several books and academic journals .
But in the 10,000 years since the invention of agriculture and its consequent major change in the human diet , natural selection has had too little time to make the optimal genetic adaptations to the new diet .
The Paleolithic diet consists of foods that can be hunted and fished , such as meat , offal and seafood , and can be gathered , such as eggs , insects , fruit , nuts , seeds , vegetables , mushrooms , herbs and spices .
According to certain proponents of the Paleolithic diet , practitioners should derive about 56 â `` 65 % of their food energy from animal foods and 36 â `` 45 % from plant foods .

The Order of St. John today forms part of the Canadian national honors system , and the Priory , established in 1946 out of the Commandery of Canada , is the largest outside of the United Kingdom , with some 6,000 members .

However , post-nominal letters of the order are not used outside the organization itself , and a Knight and Dame may not use the prefix sir or dame , though they may request from their local heraldic authority a personal coats of arms , should they not already possess any , and have it adorned with emblems of the Order of St. John .

The sopra -LRB- or supra -RRB- vest is a long drape of thin , black cloth that buttons close down the neck and to one side , falling to the ankles and cut so as to entirely cover the body .

On recommendation of that body , the Grand Prior appoints all the Grand Officers , besides himself , and may also appoint members of either Grade I or Grade II as other officers , known as the Principal Officers , such as the Secretary-General , and honorary officers , such as the Genealogist , who all hold office for a period not exceeding three years .
In 1877 , the order established at large railway centres and mining districts various St. John Ambulance associations , so that railway men and colliers could learn how to treat victims of accidents ; in 1882 , the Grand Priory founded a hospice and ophthalmic dispensary in Jerusalem -LRB- Known today as the St. John of Jerusalem Eye Hospital Group -RRB- ; and by 1887 , had created the St. John Ambulance Brigade , which undertook practical and life-saving work .

The Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem , is a royal order of chivalry established in 1831 and found today throughout the Commonwealth of Nations , Hong Kong , Ireland and the United States of America , with the world-wide mission `` to prevent and relieve sickness and injury , and to act to enhance the health and well-being of people anywhere in the world . ''

As citizens of a country that did not have the sovereignty of the Order of St. John vested in its head of state , American inductees who first joined the new Priory were specifically asked to only `` pay due obedience '' to the governing authorities of the order `` in all things consistent with your duty to your own country , '' thus eliminating any question of loyalty to a foreign head of state superseding American postulants ' duties as US citizens .
Male Knights Justice or Grace must carry their badges on a 16.5 mm wide ribbon at the neck , and Commanders , Officers , and Members have theirs on a 38 m straight ribbon suspended from a medal bar on the left breast , while females in all grades may wear their insignia either on a ribbon bow pinned at the left shoulder or hung from a medal bar in the men 's fashion , depending on the circumstance and clothing worn .

The Order of St. John is said to have arrived in Canada in 1648 , as the second Governor of New France , Charles de Montmagny , was a member of the original order , but it was not until 1883 that the first branch of the modern organization was established in the country , at Quebec City , growing to 12 branches by 1892 .

Any country without a Priory or Commandery of its own is assumed into the `` home priory '' of England and The Islands , many of these being smaller Commonwealth of Nations states in which the order has only a minor presence .

The Order of St. John 's biggest leap forward , however , came in 1888 , when Queen Victoria granted the society a royal charter , yet again renaming the order , this time as the Grand Priory of the Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem in England .
In 1871 , a new constitution brought about further changes to the group 's name , offering the more modest Order of Saint John of Jerusalem in England , and , five years later , Princess Alexandra , Princess of Wales , was recruited into its membership , followed by her husband , Prince Edward , Prince of Wales .
A subset of the Grand Council is the Honours and Awards Committee , which considers all recommendations for appointment or promotion into the grade of Bailiff or Dame Grand Cross , appointment or promotion into any grade of a person not resident within any priory 's territory , and advises the Grand Council in respect of the award of the Life-Saving Medal and Service Medal .
Recommendations are made by the Grand Council , and those selected have generally acted in such a manner as to strengthen the spirit of mankind as reflected in the order 's first motto , PRO FIDE and to encourage and promote humanitarian and charitable work aiding those in sickness , suffering , and\/or danger as reflected in the order 's other motto , PRO UTILITATE HOMINUM .

Grade I is limited to only the members of the Grand Council plus no more than 21 others , though any heads of state and members of the royal family of a Commonwealth realm , other Commonwealth of Nations member-state , or foreign country , may be appointed as a Bailiff or Dame Grand Cross without counting towards the total population ; All Priors , should they not already be in the grade or higher , are made a Knight or Dame of Justice upon their assignment ; this formerly enabled them , along with all Bailiffs and Dames Grand Cross , to nominate two personal Esquires , just as each Knight or Dame of Grace could nominate one personal Esquire , subject to the Grand Council 's scrutiny .

Thyme retains its flavor on drying better than many other herbs .

Fresh thyme is commonly sold in bunches of sprigs .
As with bay , thyme is slow to release its flavors so it is usually added early in the cooking process .
As usual with dried herbs less of it is required when substituted in a recipe .

As a rule of thumb , use one third as much dried as fresh thyme - a little less if it is ground .

Because it is antiseptic , thyme boiled in water and cooled is very effective against inflammation of the throat when gargled 3 times a day .
It tolerates drought well .
Thyme is sold both fresh and dried .
Thyme is best cultivated in a hot sunny location with well drained soil .

Thyme -LRB- ; spelling pronunciation -RRB- is a culinary and medicinal herb of the genus Thymus .
If the recipe does not specify fresh or dried , assume that it means fresh .
It has a particular affinity to and is often used as a primary flavor with lamb , tomatoes and eggs .

Usually when a recipe specifies ` bunch ' or ` sprig ' it means the whole form ; when it specifies spoons it means the leaves .

The Suwannee River -LRB- also spelled Suwanee River -RRB- is a major river of southern Georgia and northern Florida in the United States .
The letter S is the subject of the conclusion , P is the predicate of the conclusion , and M is the middle term .
Syllogisms of the same type are in the same row , and very similar syllogisms are in the same column .
The major premise links M with P and the minor premise links M with S. However , the middle term can be either the subject or the predicate of each premise where it appears .
With hand tuned timpani , there is no time to retune the timpani to A flat and E flat for the slow second movement in A flat .
The key is said to have a peaceful , serene feel , and was used quite often by Franz Schubert .
Felix Mendelssohn , Johann Nepomuk Hummel , John Field , and Friedrich Kalkbrenner each wrote one piano concerto in A-flat -LRB- Mendelssohn 's being for two pianos -RRB- ; they had the horns and trumpet tuned to E-flat .
Twenty-four of FrÃ dÃ ric Chopin 's piano pieces are in A-flat major , more than any other key .
A-flat major is the flattest major key Domenico Scarlatti used in his keyboard sonatas , though he used it only twice , in K. 127 and K. 130 .
Charles-Marie Widor considered A-flat major to be the second best key for flute music .
Beethoven chose A-flat major as the key of the slow movement for most of his C minor works , a practice which Anton Bruckner imitated in his first two C minor symphonies and also AntonÃ n DvoÅ Ã k in his only C minor symphony .
Since A-flat major was not often chosen as the main key for orchestral works of the 18th Century , passages or movements in the key often retained the timpani settings of the preceding movement .
In Bruckner 's Symphony No. 1 in C minor , however , the timpani are retuned between the first movement in C minor and the following in A-flat major .
Its relative minor is F minor , and its parallel minor is A-flat minor .
However , Arnold Bax 's last symphony , no. 7 , is also in the same key .
For example , Beethoven 's Symphony No. 5 in C minor has the timpani set to C and G for the first movement .
Sir Edward Elgar 's Symphony No. 1 in A-flat major is probably the best-known symphony in that key in the standard orchestral repertoire .

The resulting album contained elements of heavy metal , psychedelic rock , classic rock , and hardcore punk .
Following the release of the EPs Screaming Life -LRB- 1987 -RRB- , and Fopp -LRB- 1988 -RRB- , both for the Sub Pop record label , Soundgarden signed with the independent record label SST and went to work on its first full-length studio album .
In 1990 , the album earned a Grammy Award nomination for Best Metal Performance .

This led scientists to recognize that Walcott had barely scratched the surface of information available in the Burgess Shale , and also made it clear that the organisms did not fit comfortably into modern groups .
Describing the fossils was a vast task , pursued by Walcott until his death in 1927 .
It is famous for the exceptional preservation of the soft parts of its fossils .
The Burgess Shale Formation , located in the Canadian Rockies of British Columbia , is one of the world 's most celebrated fossil fields , and the best of its kind .
Walcott , led by scientific opinion at the time , attempted to categorise all fossils into living taxa , and as a result , the fossils were regarded as little more than curiosities at the time .
At -LRB- Middle Cambrian -RRB- old it is one of the earliest fossil beds containing the imprints of soft-parts .
It was not until 1962 that a first-hand reinvestigation of the fossils was attempted , by Alberto Simonetta .
At this point , aged 74 , he had amassed over 65,000 specimens .
He returned in 1910 with his sons , daughter , and wife , establishing a quarry on the flanks of Fossil Ridge .
The Burgess Shale was discovered by palaeontologist Charles Walcott in 1909 , towards the end of the season 's fieldwork .
The significance of soft-bodied preservation , and the range of organisms he recognized as new to science , led him to return to the quarry almost every year until 1924 .

Schleswig-Holstein comprises two parts , the former duchies of Schleswig and Holstein , both of which have passed back and forth between the Danes and Germans rulers several times .
The northernmost part of Jutland is separated by the Limfjord from the mainland , but is still commonly reckoned as part of the peninsula . It only became an island following a flood in 1825 .
The southern third of the Jutland peninsula is made up of the German Bundesland of Schleswig-Holstein .
Today , the Danish parts of Jutland belong to either of the three administrative regions North Jutland , Central Jutland or Region of Southern Denmark .
The area is called the North Jutlandic Island , Vendsyssel-Thy -LRB- after its districts -RRB- or simply Jutland north of the Limfjord ; it is only partly coterminous with the region called North Jutland .
The Danish Wadden Sea Islands and the German North Frisian Islands stretch along the southwest coast of Jutland in the German Bight .

The pollen tube of most seed plants acts as a conduit to transport sperm cells from the pollen grain , either from the stigma -LRB- in flowering plants or angiosperms -RRB- to the ovules at the base of the pistil , or directly through ovule tissue in some gymnosperms -LRB- conifers and gnetophytes -RRB- .
In maize , this single cell can grow longer than 12 inches to traverse the length of the pistil .
One sperm unites with the egg cell to produce the embryo of a new plant , while a second sperm unites with the central cell -LRB- polar nuclei -RRB- to produce the endosperm of the seed .
In angiosperms the pollen tube germinates from the pollen grain and grows the entire length through the stigma , style , ovary and ovules to reach the eggs .
The sperm cells by themselves are not motile and are carried within the tube .
Like ferns , other basal land plants , and many algae , these gymnosperms have flagellate sperm , which swim through a watery fluid to fertilize the egg cells .
As the tip of the tube reaches a synergid , it bursts and releases two sperm cells leading to a double fertilization .
In other gymnosperms -LRB- Ginkgo and cycads -RRB- the pollen tube is involved only in nutrient uptake from ovule tissue by the pollen grain , and does not convey sperm cells to the egg .
The endosperm is rich in starch , proteins and oils and is a major source of human food -LRB- e.g. , wheat , barley , rye , oats , corn -RRB-

Newton metre is a unit of torque -LRB- also called `` moment '' -RRB- in the SI system .
One newton metre is equal to the torque resulting from a force of one newton applied perpendicularly to a moment arm which is one metre long .
The symbolic form is N m or NÂ m , and sometimes hyphenated newton-metre .

And to decrypt we subtract the same keystream numbers from the ciphertext to get the plaintext .
In cryptography , a keystream is a stream of random or pseudorandom characters that are combined with a plaintext message to produce an encrypted message -LRB- the ciphertext -RRB- .
Block ciphers can also be used to produce keystreams .
The `` characters '' in the keystream can be bits , bytes , numbers or actual characters like A-Z depending on the usage case .
For instance , CTR mode is a block mode that makes a block cipher produce a keystream and thus turns the block cipher into a stream cipher .
Keystreams are used in the one-time pad cipher and in most stream ciphers .
-LRB- Such wrapping is called modular arithmetic . -RRB-
Thus 26 becomes 0 and 27 becomes 1 and so on .
To encrypt we add the keystream numbers to the plaintext .
Usually each character in the keystream is either added , subtracted or XORed with a character in the plaintext to produce the ciphertext , using modular arithmetic .
The random numbers in the keystream then have to be at least between 0 and 25 .
In this simple example we use the English alphabet of 26 characters from a-z . Thus we can not encrypt numbers , commas , spaces and other symbols .
Here the plaintext message `` attack at dawn '' is combined by addition with the keystream `` kjcngmlhylyu '' and produces the ciphertext `` kcvniwlabluh '' .
If a ciphertext number becomes larger than 25 we wrap it to a value between 0-25 .

The cocoon is made of a thread of raw silk from 300 to about 900 meters -LRB- 1,000 to 3,000 feet -RRB- long .
Like many insect species , silkworm pupae are eaten in some cultures -LRB- see Entomophagy -RRB- . In Korea they are boiled and seasoned to make a popular snack food known as beondegi .

In many parts of their range they now feed on cattle , but avoid camels .
Oxpeckers feed exclusively on the backs of large mammals .
Oxpeckers also feed on the earwax and dandruffs of mammals , although less is known about the benefits of this to the mammal , it is suspected that this is also a parasitic behavior .
They feed on ectoparasites , particularly ticks , as well as insects infecting wounds and the flesh and blood of some wounds as well .
Smaller antelope such as lechwe , duikers and reedbuck are also avoided , the smallest regularly used species is the Impala , probably because of the heavy tick load and social nature of that species .
Elephants and some antelope will actively dislodge the oxpeckers when they land .
Oxpecker\/mammal interactions are the subject of some debate and ongoing research .
Certain species are seemingly preferred , whereas others , like the Lichtenstein 's hartebeest or Topi are generally avoided .
Both the English and scientific names arise from their habit of perching on large mammals -LRB- both wild and domesticated -RRB- such as cattle or rhinoceroses , and eating ticks , botfly larvae , and other parasites .
Oxpeckers are endemic to the savanna of Sub-Saharan Africa .
Oxpeckers do eat ticks , but often the ticks that have already fed on the ungulate host and there has been no proven statistically significant link between oxpecker presence and reduced ectoparasite load .
According to the more recent studies of Muscicapoidea phylogeny , the oxpeckers are an ancient line related to Mimidae -LRB- mockingbirds and thrashers -RRB- and starlings but not particularly close to either .
This would make the two species of Buphagus something like living fossils , and elegantly demonstrates that such remnants of past evolution can possess striking and unique autapomorphic adaptations .
However one study of impalas found that impalas which were used by oxpeckers spent less time grooming themselves suggesting a reduction in parasite load .
Oxpeckers have been observed to open new wounds and enhance existing ones in order to drink the blood of their perches .
Considering the known biogeography of these groups , the most plausible explanation seems that the oxpecker lineage originated in Eastern or Southeastern Asia like the other two .
Some oxpecker hosts are intolerant of their presence .
They were originally thought to be an example of mutualism , but recent evidence suggests that oxpeckers may be parasites instead .
Other species tolerate oxpeckers while they search for ticks on the face , what one author described as `` appears ... to be an uncomfortable and invasive process .

A piÃ ata is a brightly-colored decoration made from either a clay container or cardboard shape covered with papier-m Ã cents chÃ .
Then , at the count of three , the children pull their strings all at the same time .
They are usually made of cardboard , colorfully decorated to match the birthday party theme -LRB- superhero , princess , or any other creative design -RRB- and filled with candy , chocolates , small toys and confetti .
The piÃ ata is then hung in a central location for everyone to see , but the strings are kept out of the reach of children .
In Puerto Rico , Ecuador , Peru , Venezuela , Colombia and to a lesser degree other Latin American countries , piÃ atas are traditionally present only at children birthday parties .
Toward the end of the party , usually after the cutting of the cake , an announcement is made that the piÃ ata will be ` broken ' and each child is given an empty party bag .
This opens the hidden trap-door -LRB- or ` breaks ' the piÃ ata -RRB- and the children receive a shower of candy and confetti while they rush to fill up their bags with the treats .
Colored strings -LRB- long enough to reach the ground -RRB- are attached to the bottom of the piÃ ata , where a trap-door is hidden under the decoration .
All the children gather directly underneath the piÃ ata and each child is given a string to hold .

The Indian Army should not be confused with the Army of India .
However , in 1903 the Indian Army absorbed these three armies .
Before 1858 , the precursor units of the Indian Army were units controlled by the Company and were paid for by their profits . These operated alongside units of the British Army , funded by the British government in London .
The British Indian Army was the principal army of the British Raj in India before the partition of India in 1947 . It was not designated as the British Indian Army but as the Indian Army and when used within an article or a book which has a clear historical context is often referred to as the Indian Army .
The Indian Army has its origins in the years after the Indian Rebellion of 1857 , when in 1858 the Crown took over direct rule of British India from the East India Company .
The armies of the East India Company were recruited primarily from Muslims in the Bengal Presidency , which consisted of Bengal , Bihar and Uttar Pradesh , and high caste Hindus recruited primarily from the rural plains of Oudh .
After the Mutiny , recruitment switched to what the British called the `` martial races , '' particularly Rajputs , Sikhs , Gurkhas , Pashtuns , Garhwalis , Mohyals , Dogras , Jats and Balochis .
The first army officially called the `` Indian Army '' was raised by the government of India in 1895 , existing alongside the three long-established presidency armies -LRB- the Bengal Army , the Madras Army and the Bombay Army -RRB- of the Presidencies of British India .
The term `` Indian Army '' was also sometimes used informally as a collective description of the former Presidency armies , particularly after the Indian Mutiny .
Between 1903 and 1947 this consisted of two separate entities : the Indian Army itself -LRB- made up of Indian regiments originating in India -RRB- , plus the British Army in India , which consisted of units of the British Army -LRB- with their origins in the United Kingdom -RRB- which were on a tour of duty in India .
British Army units stationed in India returned to the United Kingdom or were posted to other stations outside India and Pakistan .
It was not designated as the British Indian Army but as the Indian Army and when used within an article or a book which has a clear historical context is often referred to as the Indian Army .
This is a list of known residences of the British Royal Family . It includes historical residences , and not all of the current residences are regarded as official residences .

As of March 2004 , Air France employed 71,654 people .

A French press , also known as a press pot , coffee press , coffee plunger , cafetiere -LRB- UK -RRB- or Ñ afetiÃ re Ã piston , is a simple coffee brewing device which was invented in France in the late 19th century .
In the UK and the Netherlands the device is known as a cafetiÃ re ; the French word for a coffee maker or pot .
Because the coffee grounds remain in direct contact with the brewing water and the grounds are filtered from the water via a mesh instead of a paper filter , coffee brewed with the French press captures more of the coffee 's flavor and essential oils , which would become trapped in a traditional drip brew machine 's paper filters .
A French press requires coffee of a coarser grind than does a drip brew coffee filter , as finer grounds will seep through the press filter and into the coffee . Coffee is brewed by placing the coffee and water together , stirring it and leaving to brew for a few minutes , then pressing the plunger to trap the coffee grounds at the bottom of the beaker .

The North East MRT Line -LRB- NEL -RRB- is the third Mass Rapid Transit line in Singapore and the world 's second longest fully-underground , automated and driverless , rapid transit line after Singapore 's Circle MRT Line .
As the name implies , the line connects central Singapore to the north-eastern part of the island .
Transfer to the North South Line is provided at Dhoby Ghaut station , East West Line at Outram Park station and Circle Line at Serangoon and Dhoby Ghaut stations .
The line is 20 km long with 16 stations and operated by SBS Transit .
The future Downtown Line will interchange with the North East Line at Chinatown and Little India stations .
This line is colored purple in the rail map .
This line is the first in Singapore to be entirely underground .
Travelling from one end of this line to the other end takes around half an hour .
Calculations suggest that a typical Ophthalmosaurus could stay submerged for approximately 20 minutes or more .
The size of the eyes and the sclerotic rings suggests that Ophthalmosaurus hunted at a depth where there is not much light or that it may have hunted at night when a prey species was more active .
The eyes occupied almost all of the space in the skull and were protected by bony plates -LRB- sclerotic rings -RRB- , which most likely assisted to maintain the shape of the eyeballs against water pressure at depth .
Ophthalmosaurus chief claim to fame is its eyes which , at 4 inches in diameter , were extremely large in proportion to its body .
The swimming speed of Ophthalmosaurus has been estimated at 2.5 m\/s or greater , but even assuming a conservative speed of 1 m\/s , an Ophthalmosaurus would be able to dive to 600 meters and return to the surface within 20 minutes .

When he devised his table , Julian calendar years were identified by naming the consuls who held office that year â '' he himself stated that the `` present year '' was `` the consulship of Probus Junior '' , which was 525 years `` since the incarnation of our Lord Jesus Christ '' .
The Anno Domini dating system was devised in 525 by Dionysius Exiguus , who used it to compute the date of the Christian Easter festival , and to identify the several Easters in his Easter table , but did not use it to date any historical event .

Spontaneous abortion -LRB- also known as miscarriage -RRB- is the expulsion of an embryo or fetus due to accidental trauma or natural causes before approximately the 22nd week of gestation ; the definition by gestational age varies by country .
One study testing hormones for ovulation and pregnancy found that 61.9 % of conceptuses were lost prior to 12 weeks , and 91.7 % of these losses occurred subclinically , without the knowledge of the once pregnant woman .
Male Gray langur monkeys may attack females following male takeover , causing miscarriage .
Premature births and stillbirths are generally not considered to be miscarriages although usage of these terms can sometimes overlap .
Advancing maternal age and a patient history of previous spontaneous abortions are the two leading factors associated with a greater risk of spontaneous abortion .

Most miscarriages occur very early in pregnancy , in most cases , they occur so early in the pregnancy that the woman is not even aware that she was pregnant .
The Guttmacher Institute estimated that `` most abortions in the United States are obtained by minority women '' because minority women `` have much higher rates of unintended pregnancy . ''

Inconsistent use was reported by 49 % of those using condoms and 76 % of those using the combined oral contraceptive pill ; 42 % of those using condoms reported failure through slipping or breakage .
A pregnancy that ends before 37 weeks of gestation resulting in a live-born infant is known as a `` premature birth '' .
An abortion can occur spontaneously due to complications during pregnancy or can be induced in humans and other species . In the context of human pregnancies , an abortion induced to preserve the health of the gravida -LRB- pregnant female -RRB- is termed a therapeutic abortion , while an abortion induced for any other reason is termed an elective abortion .
A spontaneous abortion can also be caused by accidental trauma ; intentional trauma or stress to cause miscarriage is considered induced abortion or feticide .
Abortion may also be induced in animals , in the context of animal husbandry .
The Guttmacher Institute estimated there were 2,200 intact dilation and extraction procedures in the U.S. during 2000 ; this accounts for 0.17 % of the total number of abortions performed that year .
Another American study in 2002 concluded that 54 % of women who had an abortion were using a form of contraception at the time of becoming pregnant while 46 % were not .
Abortions are unsafe when performed by persons without the proper skills or outside of a medically safe environment . An estimated 42 million abortions are performed annually with 20 million of those abortions done unsafely around the world .
For example , abortion may be induced in mares that have been mated improperly , or that have been purchased by owners who did not realize the mares were pregnant , or that are pregnant with twin foals .
Some countries , such as Belgium -LRB- 11.2 out of 100 known pregnancies -RRB- and the Netherlands -LRB- 10.6 per 100 -RRB- , had a comparatively low ratio of induced abortion .
For example , in sheep , it may be caused by crowding through doors , or being chased by dogs .
In Finland and the United States , concern for the health risks posed by pregnancy in individual cases was not a factor commonly given ; however , in Bangladesh , India , and Kenya health concerns were cited by women more frequently as reasons for having an abortion .
The risk of spontaneous abortion decreases sharply after the 10th week from the last menstrual period -LRB- LMP -RRB- . One study of 232 pregnant women showed `` virtually complete -LRB- pregnancy loss -RRB- by the end of the embryonic period '' -LRB- 10 weeks LMP -RRB- with a pregnancy loss rate of only 2 percent after 8.5 weeks LMP .
In the context of human pregnancies , an abortion induced to preserve the health of the gravida -LRB- pregnant female -RRB- is termed a therapeutic abortion , while an abortion induced for any other reason is termed an elective abortion .
Later abortions are more common in China , India , and other developing countries than in developed countries .

Solar box cookers can be made of locally available materials or be manufactured in a factory for sale .
They range from small cardboard devices , suitable for cooking a single meal when the sun is shining , to wood and glass boxes built into the sunny side of a house .
Because they use no fuel and they cost nothing to run , humanitarian organizations are promoting their use worldwide to help slow deforestation and desertification , caused by using wood as fuel for cooking .
Although invented by Horace de Saussure , a Swiss naturalist , as early as 1767 , solar box cookers have only gained popularity since the 1970s .
A solar oven or solar cooker is a device which uses sunlight as its energy source .
Cyanides are produced by certain bacteria , fungi , and algae and are found in a number of plants .
Hydrogen cyanide is produced when a solution containing a labile cyanide is acidified because HCN is a weak acid ; alkaline solutions are safer to use because they do not evolve hydrogen cyanide .
In plants , cyanides are usually bound to sugar molecules in the form of cyanogenic glycosides and defend the plant against herbivores .

The Black and Tans was one of two newly recruited bodies , composed largely of British World War I veterans , employed by the Royal Irish Constabulary as Temporary Constables from 1920 to 1921 to suppress revolution in Ireland .
Although it was established to target the Irish Republican Army , it became notorious through its numerous attacks on the Irish civilian population .

Year 1582 -LRB- MDLXXXII -RRB- was a common year starting on Monday -LRB- link will display the full calendar -RRB- of the Julian calendar . However , this year also saw the beginning of the Gregorian Calendar switch , when a Papal bull introduced the Gregorian calendar , adopted by Spain , Portugal , the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth and most of present-day Italy from the start .
Other countries continued using the Julian calendar , switching calendars in later years , and the complete conversion of the Gregorian calendar was not entirely done until 1929 .
In these countries , the year continued as normal until Thursday , October 4 .

The Alaskan Klee Kai is a northern breed of dog of spitz type .

A video projector , also known as a digital projector , may be built into a cabinet with a rear-projection screen -LRB- rear-projection television , or RPTV -RRB- to form a single unified display device , now popular for â home theaterâ applications .
Video projectors are widely used for conference room presentations , classroom training , home theater and live events applications .
A video projector is a device that receives a video signal and projects the corresponding image on a projection screen using a lens system .
Common display resolutions for a portable projector include SVGA -LRB- 800 Ã -- 600 pixels -RRB- , XGA -LRB- 1024 Ã -- 768 pixels -RRB- , 720p -LRB- 1280 Ã -- 720 pixels -RRB- , and 1080p -LRB- 1920 Ã -- 1080 pixels -RRB- .
All video projectors use a very bright light to project the image , and most modern ones can correct any curves , blurriness , and other inconsistencies through manual settings .

Ceratophyllum is a cosmopolitan genus of flowering plants , commonly found in ponds , marshes , and quiet streams in tropical and in temperate regions .
Ceratophyllum grows completely submerged , usually , though not always , floating on the surface , and does not tolerate drought .
At intervals along nodes of the stem they produce rings of bright green leaves , which are narrow and often much-branched .

Carson was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by Jimmy Carter .
She began writing stories -LRB- often involving animals -RRB- at age eight , and had her first story published at age eleven .
After a summer course at the Marine Biological Laboratory , she continued her studies in zoology and genetics at Johns Hopkins in the fall of 1929 .
The series of fifty-two seven-minute programs focused on aquatic life and was intended to generate public interest in fish biology and in the work of the bureauâ '' a task the several writers before Carson had not managed .
Though admitted to graduate standing at Johns Hopkins University in 1928 , she was forced to remain at the Pennsylvania College for Women for her senior year due to financial difficulties ; she graduated magna cum laude in 1929 .
She had intended to continue for a doctorate , but in 1934 Carson was forced to leave Johns Hopkins to search for a full-time teaching position to help support her family .
Together , her sea trilogy explores the whole of ocean life , from the shores to the surface to the deep sea .
Rachel Carson was born on May 27 , 1907 , on a small family farm near Springdale , Pennsylvania , just up the Allegheny River from Pittsburgh .
After false starts with pit vipers and squirrels , she completed a dissertation project on the embryonic development of the pronephros in fish .
The natural world , particularly the ocean , was the common thread of her favorite literature .
She originally studied English , but switched her major to biology in January 1928 , though she continued contributing to the school 's student newspaper and literary supplement .
In 1935 , her father died suddenly , leaving Carson to care for her aging mother and making the financial situation even more critical .
Silent Spring , while met with fierce denial from chemical companies , spurred a reversal in national pesticide policyâ '' leading to a nationwide ban on DDT and other pesticidesâ '' and the grassroots environmental movement the book inspired led to the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency .
At the Pennsylvania College for Women -LRB- today known as Chatham University -RRB- , as in high school , Carson was somewhat of a loner .
The result was Silent Spring -LRB- 1962 -RRB- , which brought environmental concerns to an unprecedented portion of the American public .
Rachel Louise Carson -LRB- May 27 , 1907 â `` April 14 , 1964 -RRB- was an American marine biologist and conservationist whose writings are credited with advancing the global environmental movement .
Her next book , The Edge of the Sea , and the republished version of her first book , Under the Sea Wind , were also bestsellers .
At the urging of her undergraduate biology mentor Mary Scott Skinker , she settled for a temporary position with the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries , writing radio copy for a series of weekly educational broadcasts entitled `` Romance Under the Waters '' .
An avid reader , she also spent a lot of time exploring around her family 's 65 a farm .
Carson also began submitting articles on marine life in the Chesapeake Bay , based on her research for the series , to local newspapers and magazines .
Carson 's supervisor , pleased with the success of the radio series , asked her to write the introduction to a public brochure about the fisheries bureau ; he also worked to secure her the first full-time position that became available .
Her widely praised 1951 bestseller The Sea Around Us won her financial security and recognition as a gifted writer .
After her first year of graduate school , Carson became a part-time student , taking an assistantship in Raymond Pearl 's laboratory , where she worked with rats and Drosophila , to earn money for tuition .
Carson attended Springdale 's small school through tenth grade , then completed high school in nearby Parnassus , Pennsylvania , graduating in 1925 at the top of her class of forty-four students .
She especially enjoyed the St. Nicholas Magazine -LRB- which carried her first published stories -RRB- , the works of Beatrix Potter , and the novels of Gene Stratton Porter , and in her teen years , Herman Melville , Joseph Conrad and Robert Louis Stevenson .
Sitting for the civil service exam , she outscored all other applicants and in 1936 became only the second woman to be hired by the Bureau of Fisheries for a full-time , professional position , as a junior aquatic biologist .
In the late 1950s , Carson turned her attention to conservation and the environmental problems caused by synthetic pesticides .
Carson began her career as a biologist in the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries , and became a full-time nature writer in the 1950s .
A context switch can mean a register context switch , a task context switch , a thread context switch , or a process context switch .
A context switch is the computing process of storing and restoring state -LRB- context -RRB- of a CPU so that execution can be resumed from the same point at a later time . This enables multiple processes to share a single CPU .
However , depending on the operating system , a context switch may also take place at this time .
What constitutes the context is determined by the processor and the operating system .
The context switch is an essential feature of a multitasking operating system .
Context switches are usually computationally intensive and much of the design of operating systems is to optimize the use of context switches .

David James `` Mac '' McAllister -LRB- born 12 January 1971 -RRB- is a German politician of the conservative Christian Democratic Union -LRB- CDU -RRB- .

They have two daughters named Jamie Elizabeth and Mia Louise .

The sickle-claws of the dromaeosaurid Deinonychus have a curvature of 160 degrees , well within the range of climbing animals .
It is now known that at least some , and probably all , dromaeosaurids were covered in feathers , including large , vaned , wing and tail feathers .
Ostrom compared Deinonychus to the ostrich and cassowary .
Like other theropods , dromaeosaurids were bipedal ; that is , they walked on their hind legs .
Dromaeosaurids were small to medium-sized dinosaurs , ranging from about 0.7 meters in length -LRB- 2.3 ft , in the case of Mahakala -RRB- to over 6 m -LRB- 20 ft , in Utahraptor and Achillobator -RRB- .
Turner et al . also inferred that flight evolved only in the Avialae , and these two points suggested that the ancestral dromaeosaurid could not glide or fly .
The enlarged second toe bore an unusually large , curved sickle-shaped claw -LRB- held off the ground or ` retracted ' when walking -RRB- , which is thought to have been used in capturing prey and climbing trees -LRB- see `` Claw function '' below -RRB- .
He noted that the bird species can inflict serious injury with the large claw on the second toe .
Martin asserted for decades that birds were unrelated to maniraptorans , but in 2004 he changed his position , and now he agrees that the two are the closest of relatives .
The depiction of the dromaeosaurid in the original Jurassic Park film , while accurate for its time , is now known to have been inaccurate in many respects , including the lack of feathers .
However , the dimensions of the Velociraptor in the film are much larger than the largest members of that genus .
In 2002 , Hwang and colleagues utilized the work of Norell et al . , including new characters and better fossil evidence , to determine that birds -LRB- avialans -RRB- were better thought of as cousins to the dromaeosaurids and troodontids .
The authorship of the family Dromaeosauridae is credited to William Diller Matthew and Barnum Brown , who erected it as a subfamily -LRB- Dromaeosaurinae -RRB- of the family Deinodontidae in 1922 , containing only the new genus Dromaeosaurus .
Some may have grown larger ; undescribed specimens of Utahraptor in BYU collections belonged to individuals that may have reached up to 11 m long , though these await more detailed study .
Xu and colleagues in 2003 cited the basal position of Microraptor , along with feather and wing features , as evidence that the ancestral dromaeosaur could glide .
Many other dromaeosaurid fossils have been found with feathers covering their bodies , some with fully-developed feathered wings .
Another species of dromaeosaurid , Microraptor gui , may have been capable of gliding using its well-developed wings on both the fore and hind limbs .
Most of the tail vertebrae bear bony , rod-like extensions , as well as bony tendons in some species .
In 2002 , Hwang et al . found that Microraptor was the most primitive dromaeosaur .
A consensus of paleontologists has concluded that there is not yet enough evidence to determine whether any dromaeosaurs could fly or glide , or whether they evolved from ancestors that could .
The first , Rahonavis ostromi -LRB- originally classified as avian bird , but found to be a dromaeosaurid in later studies -RRB- may have been capable of powered flight , as indicated by its long forelimbs with evidence of quill knob attachments for long sturdy flight feathers .
Velociraptor , a dromaeosaurid , gained much attention after it was featured prominently in the 1993 Steven Spielberg film Jurassic Park .
It has been proposed that this tail was used as a stabilizer and\/or counterweight while running or in the air ; in Microraptor , an elongate diamond-shaped fan of feathers is preserved on the end of the tail .
The ability to fly or glide has been suggested for at least two dromaeosaurid species .
However , one well-preserved specimen of Velociraptor mongoliensis -LRB- IGM 100\/986 -RRB- has an articulated tail skeleton that is curved horizontally in a long S-shape .
The current consensus among paleontologists agrees with the findings of Hwang et al . -LRB- 2002 -RRB- ; that dromaeosaurids are most closely related to the troodontids , and together with the troodontids form the clade Deinonychosauria .
Dromaeosauridae , along with Troodontidae , make up the infraorder Deinonychosauria .
Both the first and second toes on each foot of B. bondoc were also held retracted and bore enlarged , sickle-shaped claws .
Martin believes that maniraptorans are secondarily flightless birds , and that birds evolved from nonâ `` dinosaurian archosaurs , so that most of the species formerly called theropods would now not even be classified as dinosaurs .
Dromaeosauridae was first defined as a clade by Paul Sereno in 1998 , as the most inclusive natural group containing Dromaeosaurus but not Troodon , Ornithomimus or Passer .
A possible third lineage of giant dromaeosaurs is represented by isolated teeth found on the Isle of Wight , England .
While Jurassic Park III attempted to address this last oversight by adding quill-like structures around the head of some of its dromaeosaurs , they did not resemble the structure or distribution of actual dromaeosaurid feathers known from fossil remains .
Other researchers , like Larry Martin believe that dromaeosaurs , along with all maniraptorans are not dinosaurs at all .
This had been interpreted as evidence that these dromaeosaurs hunted in coordinated packs like some modern mammals .
Previous studies had shown that the amount of curvature in a claw corresponded to what lifestyle the animal has : animals with strongly curved claws of a certain shape tend to be climbers , while straighter claws indicate ground-dwelling lifestyles .
Other fossils , which do not preserve actual impressions of feathers , still preserve the associated bumps on the forearm bones where long wing feathers would have attached in life .
Deinonychus fossils have been uncovered in small groups near the remains of the herbivore Tenontosaurus , a larger ornithischian dinosaur .
The forelimbs of Rahonavis were more powerfully built than Archaeopteryx , and show evidence that they bore strong ligament attachments necessary for flapping flight .
Luis Chiappe concluded that , given these adaptations , Rahonavis could probably fly but would have been more clumsy in the air than modern birds .
However , not all paleontologists found the evidence conclusive , and a subsequent study published in 2007 by Roach and Brinkman suggests that the Deinonychus may have actually displayed a disorganized mobbing behavior .
Michael Crichton adopted this synonymization of the two genera in his novels , on which the first two films were based .
The seriema also has an enlarged second toe claw , and uses it to tear apart small prey items for swallowing .
However , whereas other theropods walked with three toes contacting the ground , fossilized footprint tracks confirm that most dromaeosaurids held the second toe off the ground in a hyperextended position , with only the third and fourth toes bearing the weight of the animal .
Overall , this feather pattern looks very much like Archaeopteryx .
When John Ostrom described it for Deinonychus in 1969 , he interpreted the claw as a blade-like slashing weapon , much like the canines of some saber-toothed cats , used with powerful kicks to cut into prey .
There is currently disagreement about the function of the enlarged `` sickle claw '' on the second toe .
Dromaeosaurids also appear in many of The Land Before Time films , beginning with the third .
One dromaeosaur species , Balaur bondoc , also possessed a first toe which was highly modified in parallel with the second .
Chatterjee also found that Microraptor had the basic requirements to sustain level powered flight in addition to gliding .
In that case the larger dromaeosaurs would be secondarily terrestrialâ '' having lost the ability to glide later in their evolutionary history .
A 2005 study by Sankar Chatterjee suggested that the wings of Microraptor functioned like a split-level `` biplane '' , and that it likely employed a phugoid style of gliding , in which it would launch from a perch and swoop downward in a ` U ' shaped curve , then lift again to land on another tree , with the tail and hind wings helping to control its position and speed .
The interpretation of the sickle claw as a killing weapon applied to all dromaeosaurids .
Microraptor even shows evidence of a second pair of wings on the hind legs .
The forelimb claws they studied also fell within the climbing range of curvature .
The dromaeosaurids Rahonavis and Velociraptor have both been found with quill knobs , showing that these forms had feathers despite no impressions having been found .
The cassowary has claws up to 125 m long .
A challenge to all of these alternative scenarios came when Turner and colleagues in 2007 described a new dromaeosaurid , Mahakala , which they found to be the most basal and most primitive member of the Dromaeosauridae , more primitive than Microraptor .
Mahakala is both the most primitive dromaeosaurid ever described and the smallest .
Based on this cladistic analysis , Mahakala suggests that the ancestral condition for dromaeosaurids is non-volant .
Mahakala had short arms and no ability to glide .
In Manning 's interpretation , the second toe claw would be used as a climbing aid when subduing bigger prey and also as stabbing weapon .
Some dromaeosaurid fossils preserve long , pennaceous feathers on the hands and arms -LRB- remiges -RRB- and tail -LRB- rectrices -RRB- , as well as shorter , down-like feathers covering the body .
In his study of Deinonychus , Ostrom proposed that these features stiffened the tail so that it could only flex at the base , and the whole tail would then move as a single , rigid , lever .
Adams -LRB- 1987 -RRB- suggested that the talon was used to disembowel large ceratopsian dinosaurs .
The individuals were spaced about one meter apart , and retained the same direction of travel , walking at a fairly slow pace .
While the trackways clearly do not represent hunting behavior , the idea that groups of dromaeosaurs may have hunted together could not be ruled out .
As late as 2001 , Mark Norell and colleagues analyzed a large survey of coelurosaur fossils and produced the tentative result that dromaeosaurids were most closely related to birds , with troodontids as a more distant outgroup .
This evidence , combined with the small size of other primitive relatives such as Microraptor and the troodontid Anchiornis , indicates that the common ancestor of dromaeosaurids , troodontids , and birds â `` which is called the ancestral paravian â `` may have been very small , at around 65 cm in length and 600 to 700 grams of mass.
Deinonychosaurians in turn are the sister taxon to avialans , and therefore the closest relatives of avialan birds .
This may have been used as an aerodynamic stabilizer and rudder during gliding and\/or powered flight -LRB- see `` Flight and gliding '' below -RRB- .
The Manning team also compared the curvature of the dromaeosarid `` sickle claw '' on the foot with curvature in modern birds and mammals .
While direct feather impressions are only possible in fine-grained sediments , some fossils found in coarser rocks show evidence of feathers by the presence of quill knobs , the attachment points for wing feathers possessed by some birds .
Robert Bakker recalled that Spielberg had been disappointed with the dimensions of Velociraptor and so upsized it , adding that soon afterwards he named Utahraptor which was more the size depicted , or larger .
In addition to confirming the hypothesis that the sickle-claw was held retracted off the ground , the trackway -LRB- made by a large , Achillobator-sized species -RRB- showed evidence of six individuals of about equal size moving together along a shoreline .
This development , first hypothesized in the mid-late 1980s and confirmed by fossil discoveries in 1999 , represents a significant change in the way dromaeosaurids have historically been depicted in art and film -LRB- see â Feathersâ below -RRB- .
Paleontologist Peter Mackovicky commented on the Manning team 's study , stating that small , primitive dromaeosaurids -LRB- such as Microraptor -RRB- were likely to have been tree-climbers , but that climbing did not explain why later , gigantic dromaeosaurids such as Achillobator retained highly curved claws when they were too large to have climbed trees .
The teeth belong to an animal the size of the dromaeosaurine Utahraptor , but they appear to belong to velociraptorines , judging by the shape of the teeth .
This suggests that , in life , the tail could bend from side to side with a substantial degree of flexibility .
Dromaeosaurids had long tails .
The authors of the paper describing these footprints interpreted the trackways as evidence that some species of dromaeosaurs lived in groups .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat roosts in the caves of limestone hills , far from the entrance .
The wings seem to be shaped for hovering flight , and the gut contents of specimens do include spiders and insects that are presumably gleaned off foliage .
During feeding periods , the young either stays in the roost or remains attached to the mother at one of her two vestigial pubic nipples .
There is a large web of skin between the hind legs -LRB- the uropatagium -RRB- which may assist in flying and catching insects , although there are no tail bones or calcars to help control it in flight .
Its common name refers to its discoverer , Thai zoologist Kitti Thonglongya .
In Thailand , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is restricted to a small region of Kanchanaburi Province , within the drainage basin of the Khwae Noi River .
While many caves contain only 10 to 15 individuals , the average group size is 100 , with a maximum of about 500 .
Individuals roost high on walls or roof domes , far apart from each other .
Threats to the Burmese population are not well known .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat -LRB- Craseonycteris thonglongyai -RRB- , also known as the bumblebee bat , is a vulnerable species of bat and the only member of the family Craseonycteridae .
Late in the dry season -LRB- around April -RRB- of each year , females give birth to a single offspring .
Soon after the bat 's discovery in the 1970s , some roosting sites became disturbed as a result of tourism , scientific collection , and even the collection and sale of individuals as souvenirs .
During this period , the bat forages within fields of cassava and kapok or around the tops of bamboo clumps and teak trees , within one kilometre of the roosting site .
Another potential risk is the activity of local monks , who have occupied roost caves during periods of meditation .
However , these pressures may not have had a significant effect on the species as a whole , since many small colonies exist in hard-to-access locations , and only a few major caves were disturbed .
In 2007 , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat was identified by the Evolutionarily Distinct and Globally Endangered -LRB- EDGE -RRB- project as one of its Top 10 `` focal species '' .
The bat 's upperparts are reddish-brown or gray , while the underside is generally paler .
While the Sai Yok National Park contains much of the bat 's range , some Thai populations occur outside the park and are therefore unprotected .
The dental formula is 1:1:1:3 in the upper jaw and 2:1:2:3 in the lower jaw , with large upper incisors .
Currently , the most significant and long-term threat to the Thai population could be the annual burning of forest areas , which is most prevalent during the bat 's breeding season .
The Thai and Burmese populations are morphologically identical , but their echolocation calls are distinct .
These short flights are easily interrupted by heavy rain or cold temperatures .
The bat feeds during short activity periods in the evening and dawn , foraging around nearby forest areas for insects .
Nevertheless , most prey is probably caught in flight .
Colonies range greatly in size , with an average of 100 individuals per cave .
Based on this determination , the bat 's closest relatives are members of the families Hipposideridae and Rhinopomatidae .
Despite having two caudal vertebrae , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat has no visible tail .
Bats also undertake seasonal migration between caves .
Main staples of the bat 's diet include small flies -LRB- Chloropidae , Agromyzidae , and Anthomyiidae -RRB- , hymenopterans , and psocopterans .
It is not known whether the two populations are reproductively isolated .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat occupies the limestone caves along rivers , within dry evergreen or deciduous forests .
Its teeth are typical of an insectivorous bat .
The wings are relatively large and darker in color , with long tips that allow the bat to hover .
Since the 2001 discovery of a single individual in Burma , at least nine separate sites have been identified in the limestone outcrops outside the Thanlwin , Ataran , and Gyaing Rivers of Kayin and Mon States .
It has a reddish-brown or gray coat , with a distinctive pig-like snout .
In addition , the proposed construction of a pipeline from Burma to Thailand may have a negative impact .
The bat has a distinctive swollen , pig-like snout with thin , vertical nostrils .
Thonglongya worked with a British partner , John E. Hill , in classifying bats of Thailand ; after Thonglongya died suddenly in February 1974 , Hill formally described the species , giving it the binomial name Craseonycteris thonglongyai in honor of his colleague .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat was unknown to the world at large prior to 1974 .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat has a brief activity period , leaving its roost for only 30 minutes in the evening and 20 minutes at dawn .
Its ears are relatively large , while its eyes are small and mostly concealed by fur .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is the only extant species in the family Craseonycteridae , which is grouped in the superfamily Rhinolophoidea as a result of molecular testing .
It occurs in western Thailand and southeast Burma , where it occupies limestone caves along rivers .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is the smallest species of bat and the world 's smallest mammal .
As of the species ' most recent review in 2008 , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is listed by the IUCN as vulnerable , with a downward population trend .

Janko Prunk -LRB- born December 30 , 1942 -RRB- is a Slovenian historian of modern history .
Prunk has been actively involved in politics .
In 1976 , he obtained his PhD with a thesis on the relationship between the Slovenian Christian Socialist movement and the Communist Party of Slovenia within the Liberation Front of the Slovenian People , which was still a controversial topic at that time .
Prunk was born in the small settlement of Loka pri Zidanem Mostu -LRB- part of the municipality of Sevnica -RRB- , in central Slovenia , which was then the German-occupied Lower Styria .
As an early admirer of JoÅ 3\/4 e PuÄ nik , Prunk joined the Democratic Opposition of Slovenia after the democratization of Slovenia .
Between 1992 and 1993 , Prunk served as Minister for Slovenes outside Slovenia and National Minorities in Slovenia in the first coalition cabinet of Janez DrnovÅ ek .
Janko Prunk has written over 400 specialized articles , and 15 books , since 1966 .
His book , A brief history of Slovenia : Historical background of the Republic of Slovenia , is one of the most comprehensive works on modern Slovenian history .
He has also written on the history of political movements in Slovenia from the end of 19th century until World War II , especially about Slovene Christian socialism and the history of Slovenian national questions .
Prunk is a member of Institute of European History in Mainz , and a senior fellow of the Center for European Integration Studies in Bonn .
He has published articles and monographs on analytical politology , modern history , the genesis of modern political formations , and the history of social and political philosophy in Slovenia .
He was an active member of the Slovenian Democratic Party -LRB- known as Slovenian Social Democratic Party between 1989 and 2003 -RRB- .
After the split with the party , he became very critical of the then Prime Minister Janez JanÅ a , whom he accused of being a `` liberal with an authoritative touch , who aspires at becoming a Slovenian PiÅ sudski '' .
From 1966 to 1995 , he collaborated with the Institute for modern history in Ljubljana .
He obtained his Master 's degree from University of Ljubljana in 1972 .
In 1984 and 1988 , Prunk was awarded scholarships by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation , which enabled him to continue his studies in Cologne and Freiburg .
Between 2004 and 2008 , he served as chairman of the Slovenian Democratic Party 's internal Committee for Education Policies . He resigned in 2008 because of disagreements over the Government 's policy favoring private universities .

A compact fluorescent lamp -LRB- CFL -RRB- , also known as a compact fluorescent light or energy saving light -LRB- or less commonly as a compact fluorescent tube -RRB- , is a type of fluorescent lamp .
Many CFLs are designed to replace an incandescent lamp and can fit into most existing light fixtures formerly used for incandescents .
In the United States , a CFL has a higher purchase price than an incandescent lamp , but can save over US$ 40 in electricity costs over the lamp 's lifetime .
Black light CFLs , those with UVA generating phosphor , are much more efficient than incandescent black light lamps , since the amount of UV light that the filament of the incandescent lamp produces is only a fraction of the generated spectrum .
Compared to general service incandescent lamps giving the same amount of visible light , CFLs use less power and have a longer rated life .

The first football club in Chesterfield was formed as Chesterfield Town F.C. in the late 1860s .
The name `` equinox '' is derived from the Latin aequus -LRB- equal -RRB- and nox -LRB- night -RRB- , because around the equinox , the night and day have approximately equal length .
An equinox occurs twice a year , when the tilt of the Earth 's axis is inclined neither away from nor towards the Sun , the center of the Sun being in the same plane as the Earth 's equator . The term equinox can also be used in a broader sense , meaning the date when such a passage happens .

The first recorded use of baby blue as a color name in English was in 1892 .
